title: Liran Einav
text:
Liran Einav (born November 1970 in <a href="Tel%20Aviv">Tel Aviv</a>) is an American–Israeli economist and currently professor of economics at <a href="Stanford%20University">Stanford University</a>. His research focuses on <a href="industrial%20organization">industrial organization</a>, <a href="Health%20economics">health</a> and <a href="Regulatory%20economics">regulation</a>.
Early life and education.
From 1988 to 1996, Einav served as a captain in the intelligence unit of the <a href="Israeli%20Defense%20Forces">Israeli Defense Forces</a>.
Following military service, he enrolled at <a href="Tel%20Aviv%20University">Tel Aviv University</a> and graduated with a BA in <a href="computer%20science">computer science</a> and economics in 1997. He went on to further study at <a href="Harvard%20University">Harvard University</a> and received his Ph.D. in economics in 2002.
Academic career.
After graduating from Harvard University, Einav's first academic position was as an assistant professor at Stanford University. He was granted <a href="Academic%20tenure">tenure</a> and promoted to associate professor in 2007 and full professor in 2012.
He has served in an editorial capacity for various academic journals such as "<a href="The%20American%20Economic%20Review">The American Economic Review</a>", "<a href="Econometrica">Econometrica</a>" and "".
He was elected fellow of the <a href="Econometric%20Society">Econometric Society</a> and the <a href="American%20Academy%20of%20Arts%20and%20Sciences">American Academy of Arts and Sciences</a> in 2012 and 2015, respectively.
